description: A mondegreen of and per se and, meaning “and by itself & (the character)”, which is how the symbol ⟨&⟩ was originally referred to in English. This formulation is due to the old practice in schools whereby, when reciting the alphabet, the ⟨&⟩ sign was treated as a 27th letter (read as “and”), and any letter that could also be used as a word in itself (⟨A⟩, ⟨I⟩, ⟨O⟩ and, at the time, ⟨&⟩) was preceded by the Latin expression per se (“by itself”). Thus the end of the recitation would be: “X, Y, Z and per se and”. This last phrase eventually became ampersand, and the term was in common English usage by around 1837.

examples: The ampersand character in many logics acts as an operator connecting two propositions.

verbs.description: ampersand (third-person singular simple present ampersands, present participle ampersanding, simple past and past participle ampersanded)

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To add an ampersand to.
